awd_abstract_narration:
Positronium is an exotic hydrogen-like atom composed of one ordinary electron (the light mass negatively charged components of all ordinary matter) bound to one positively charged electron, the antimatter twin of the electron, called a positron. Positronium has a brief existence which terminates in its annihilation into a burst of two or three gamma ray photons (very high energy particles of light). The primary goal of the project is to produce a high density positronium gas and cool it to produce the first positronium "superfluid", known as a Bose-Einstein condensate. This substance is predicted to exhibit stimulated annihilation, in which one annihilation gamma ray photon induces the emission of others of exactly the same direction and energy, the essential activity required for all types of laser action. The second goal of the project is to obtain evidence for this stimulated annihilation to open the way for the first highly penetrating annihilation gamma ray lasers. Besides the scientific interest in the phenomena, the possible eventual benefits include medical applications to radiography and radiation therapy, defense and other uses of high-power gamma ray beams, and the possibility of gamma ray laser ignition of fusion for clean, low-cost electric power generating plants.
 

The principle goals of the project are to (1) produce and observe a Bose-Einstein condensate of positronium and (2) to obtain evidence for the stimulated emission of its two-photon annihilation radiation. The project will use an existing slow positron beam and magnetic trap system that produces nanosecond pulses of about 100 million 30% spin-polarized positrons. The positrons will be extracted from the confining magnetic field of the trap and focused in a 200 micron diameter spot on a thin metal film that efficiently emits slow positrons. These will be accelerated and focused to a 5 micron spot onto a target containing cavities within which high density positronium will be formed and thermalized to low temperatures. The positronium temperature will be measured as a function of time by the angular correlation of the annihilation photon pairs using an existing detector. The presence of a condensate will be inferred from its sub-thermal apparent temperature. Various cavity geometries will be used to achieve the required high positronium densities and sufficiently cold positronium temperatures around 10 K. Having made the first positronium Bose-Einstein condensate, a search will be made for the stimulated emission of its annihilation gamma rays. Besides enabling the production of the first gamma ray lasers, this work will open the way for other topics involving high density positrons, including the first production and studies of the positronium positive ion (the bound state of two positrons and one electron), formation of a positronium atom laser beam, and production of Bose-Einstein condensed positronium bubbles in superfluid helium-4.

Project Title: Spectroscopy of Dense Positronium
Report Type: Final Project Report
PI: Allen Mills,  co-PI’s: Harry Tom and Gabriel Cecchini
Awardee: University of California-Riverside
Program Officer Name: John D. Gillaspy
Program Officer Email: jgillasp@nsf.gov
Program Officer Phone Number: (703)292-7173

2024 August 31 Report 2011836 Spectroscopy of Dense Positronium 

Objectives and results. Our primary objectives are (1) to make the first observation of positive positronium ions made from two positrons bound to a single electron and (2) to form the first Bose-Einstein condensate made from positronium atoms.

Our positron beam currently produces high density pulses of positrons that are absorbed by a Ni single-crystal foil remoderator. About half of the positrons thermalize in the solid and diffuse to the exit surface where about half of them may be emitted into the vacuum as slow positrons or slow positronium atoms, while the remaining positrons become stuck to the surface of the metal where their density will be on the order of 1011 cm-2. Interactions of these surface positrons with the positrons that are being emitted will allow the formation of about 103 positive positronium ions per pulse. This will be sufficient for identifying the ions and for observing their lowest energy Feshbach resonance using laser spectroscopy.

Forming a Ps BEC will require implanting about 108 partially polarized positrons into a suitable target in which Ps will form and cool to low temperature. The presence of a BEC will be inferred from the extreme narrowness of the angular distribution of the 2-gamma annihilation radiation (ACAR) emitted after the Ps is quenched by the application of 25 ns 0.5 T transverse magnetic field pulses. We have worked out a plausible scheme for achieving the necessary Ps densities in a target cavity fabricated from diamond and porous silica.

As stated above, the positrons must be compressed to high phase space densities by focusing to a small diameter and remoderation in a thin single-crystal Ni foil. Having been been worried that the positrons would lose their spin polarization upon slowing down in the 1 T average internal magnetic field of the foil, we did an experiment [1] which showed that the thermalized positrons see only a small average field that does not significantly affect their polarization. We are now doing preliminary experiments to make the first observations of the Ps+ ion and to measure its photoionization cross section and width at the lowest Feshbach resonance expected at 229 nm. These activities bring us closer to our goal of making a Ps BEC using 10 times higher positron beam areal densities than before.

We have been working on increasing the polarizaton following the work of Rich et al. To increase the polarization we attenuate the slower positrons using a thin layer of frozen Ar that covers the positron radioactive source (currently 10 mCi Na-22). The more energetic positrons (the polarization is proportional to the positron velocity) selectively produce more highly polarized slow positrons using a conical solid Ne moderator. We expect the polarization to be about 60%, double our current polarization. While the polarized slow positron count rate using this process will be reduced by a factor of about 4, the number of positrons per positron pulse will remain constant by the expedient of collecting positrons in our accumulator for a longer time.

We have also recently been working on a slow positron density increasing device using slow positron drift in a focusing electric field in a 15 micron thick solid diamond target. The positrons will escape from the exit side of the target into a porous silica TEOS target containing 100 nm spherical voids or rod-like voids into which a BEC can accumulate. The target will be provided with a sub mm pulsed magnetic field to partially quench the triplet BEC to the singlet state upon demand. The resulting singlet decays into two photons will allow us to measure the temperature distribution of the positronium, thus providing evidence for the presence of a BEC.

Opportunities for training and professional development - UCR Positron Summer School

In a manner similar to the previous year, we invited twelve UCR undergraduate students from the PI's Spring 2024 Physics 139L Electronics Lab course and from his Winter 2024 Physics 245 "Positron Physics" course to join in an informal "2024 Positron Summer School" from July 1 - September 20, 2024. These students were joined by two other students about to start in the MS&E program at UCR. The topic was "Positronium 1S-2S measurements and the positronium BEC". The students were supervised by our 8 graduate students, all under the supervision of post-doctoral scholar Dr. Gabriel Cecchini.

[1] G. G. Cecchini, R. G. Greaves, and A. P. Mills, Jr., “Conservation of longitudinal spin polarization of positrons emitted from a thin Ni(100) foil”. Phys. Rev. A 107, 062809 (2023).
